PUBLICATIONSTMT.PUBLISHER: Michigan Corpus of Academic Spoken English, English Language Institute, University of Michigan

AVAILABILITY.P: The MICASE project is owned by the Regents of the University of Michigan, who hold the copyright. The database has been developed by the English Language Institute, and the web interface by Digital Library Production Services. The original DAT audiotapes are held in the English Language Institute and may be consulted by bona fide researchers under special arrangements. The database is freely available at this website for study, teaching and research purposes, and copies of the transcripts may be distributed, as long as either this statement of availability or the citation given below appears in the text. However, if any portion of this material is to be used for commercial purposes, such as for textbooks or tests, permission must be obtained in advance and a license fee may be required. Furthermore, some restrictions apply on the citation of specific portions of some of the transcripts in educational presentations and publications; all such restrictions are noted at the end of this statement. For further information about copyright permissions, please contact Dr. Sarah Briggs at slbriggs@umich.edu.

The recommended citation for MICASE is: R. C. Simpson, S. L. Briggs, J. Ovens, and J. M. Swales. (1999) The Michigan Corpus of Academic Spoken English. Ann Arbor, MI: The Regents of the University of Michigan
RESTRICTIONS ON CITATION OF EXAMPLES: NONE

um, i, worked for two different environmental consulting companies. uhuh um one was a, contractor to the E-P-A, and we, evaluated um, hazardous waste sites. uhuh um to see if they would be, put onto the national priorities list uh superfund list uhuh um, and then i did that for a year and a half and then i went to this other company, um, the contract ended so i got laid off mhm for a couple months, and then, um, i went over to this other company it was a private, small consulting company and then i was there for, three and a half years... three three and a half years mhm and, um, did similar sorts of um chemical contamination investigations uhuh uh property audits or real estate transactions mm if like a company is gonna, um buy a piece of property, um lot of times the banks will have them do, just an audit to see, you know if they've buried drums yeah out back kinda thing yeah or you know if the company's had any, like records of, um, violation for anything uhuh um, so i did that yeah um, i also guided whitewater rafting trips mhm um on weekends that was a lot of fun yeah ... and then, i've been, actually i applied to Michigan, um... in- a year ago mhm um, and i didn't get in so i reapplied but my fiancee, um, got in so we moved out here, and i was looking for a job, for a year so i've been here a year before mhm

um, how do you feel about your educational experience at Michigan, um so far. uh

um... i think there's there's some good things and there's some things that you know i wish were a little different. mhm um... it's, Saint Lawrence was a really small school there's two thousand people. mhm and their main focus was, educating people yeah um and not_ and research and publishing took uh was secondary. yeah um, and coming um so at Saint Lawrence um i think people_ the professors', um experience was conveying information to people. right and on a more on a really personal pers- personal level, mhm and um... here it just seems like, um, you know their their fo- they they do great work they're really intelligent, yeah they're just not as polished, at presenting_ conveying uhuh information it seemed, uhuh and that and that was a big shock, yeah
and and also i mean it could be that you know i was out of school for... six seven years and, you know it sort of glorified, school a little bit. uhuh um um... the (xx) could also be that it's so expensive and, and i'm paying for it this time instead of my parents and um, that can make, make a big difference too. yeah um so i think that's kinda the the biggest thing. mhm um.
what's been most valuable to you?

um uh i don't know mhm um probably, um... just, talking to different people in the program i've i mean i've mhm feel like i've picked up a lot of information from... from people, just other students, um, but also... um one of the professors um i'm taking a class with him now um Rob Buford has started_ h- has um, been looking at a lot of stuff um and he works a lot with Bob Seyfarth mhm um, their_ I guess their approach for looking at rivers and streams is, that, more from like a geomorphological point of view mhm that like the geology um was here first and then th- the biology of the streams and the chemistry all came after that and so that, shapes everything yeah um, just because it was here first and it's older and and there's some interactions that go on after that, that just looking at it from that perspective, um i think is really neat um, an- and that's and that's i think unique to the_ to the school yeah
there's not very many people that look at it yeah from that viewpoint right um so i think, that's probably one of the more_ the good experiences i've had uhuh uhuh
here too and my fiancee um is uh, is one of Rob Buford's students mhm and um, and she's working with Rob and Bill Redmond, and, on on, um modeling the_ all the watersheds in Michigan mhm um based on geology and seeing how that um affects the different types of streams and and the different fish that that live here uhuh so i_ i've picked up a lot through that too yeah yeah um... neat mhm.
it's the kind of insight that could really affect your thinking through your whole career and i_ yeah (things) that will, shift and perspective

mhm. and i just_ i was thinking about it the other day. um, at Saint Lawrence i took a course on fluvial geology. uhuh and it's how water moves thr- through the streams and, um, when it goes around the corner it picks up, it cuts the bank and makes a hole and then it yeah
gets it's sort of how the water shapes the channel kinda thing. right and when i took that i took all these um freshwater biology courses and i never made the connection mhm and i don't think anyone at school made the connection mhm and i'm like you know it's just, you think about it and it's so obvious yeah um yeah but if you never make the connection um, yeah it's so_ i was kinda like wondering why you know i never did it but... but then again no one else ever made the connection too right
